Award.AwardTitle: FRG:Collaborative Research: Chemically-active Viscoelastic Mixture Models in Physiology: Formulation, Analysis, and Computation
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project concerns development and analysis of mathematical models of several complex biological processes, each with major importance to the fundamental and health sciences: cellular blebbing and its role in cellular locomotion through extracellular matrix, platelet deposition and fibrin gelation in arterial blood clotting, mucin secretion and its role in acid transport in the stomach, protein sorting and trafficking by the Golgi apparatus. Although the details of the biology of these processes are vastly different, a common theme is that each involves a complex viscoelastic material mixture whose behavior is determined by the dynamic interplay of mechanics, flow, physical structure, and chemistry. The mathematical description of these processes requires equations describing multiphase flow, the evolution of composition, structure and chemistry, and the relationship between stresses and composition/structure. The solution and analysis of sophisticated models that combine these elements will pose substantial mathematical and computational challenges. To meet these challenges, the investigators will develop and apply advanced numerical algorithms to gain fundamental insights into the mechanisms of function of these important physiological processes. This work will lead to novel and important advances in understanding the essential role of the mechanics and dynamics of complex materials in the function of biological systems. This, in turn, will support improved diagnosis and treatment of a range of serious medical disorders including coronary artery disease, cancer, and metabolic disease. The work will also lead to better understanding of complex materials in general and contribute to the design of novel new materials for meeting pressing technological challenges. Furthermore, the design of new computational algorithms will lead to new capabilities in the use of high-performance computing in science and engineering. The highly interdisciplinary nature of the project will provide many opportunities for training young scientists in the new multi-disciplinary approach to science.

Many important physiological processes involve interactions between materials of different types (for example, water and cells or water and polymer gels) and which move relative to one another. The physical interactions between the materials can be strongly influenced by chemical reactions, and the chemical reactions in turn are influenced by the materials' motion and other interactions. Better insight into how such complex systems work and are regulated is critical to understanding these important processes and how they can be manipulated to improve human health. Because these processes are governed by physical and chemical principles and properties, and because these principles and properties can be expressed mathematically, mathematical tools can be brought to bear on these problems. Through mathematical analysis and computational simulations, new insights into the materials' behavior can be developed and a wealth of data can be obtained that complements the data obtainable from traditional laboratory experiments. Hence the combination of mathematical and experimental investigators brought together in this project is expected to lead to significant new insights in important physiological and pathological situations including blood clotting, metabolism, and cancer metastasis. Further the mathematics and computational tools developed in the project will impact the development of non-biological complex materials to meet pressing technological challenges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We developed a new method to simulate materials that consist of a two-phase gel in contact with a viscous fluid. The method tracks the interface between the two materials implicitly, and it uses a regularization procedure to solve the same set of equations in both materials. This formulation allows for fast and robust solvers on simple computational domains, which means that the method could be applied to a wide class of problems such as simulating fibrous blot clots in contact with the blood or the layered structure of mucus which lines the respiratory tract.

We also developed a new mixed Eulerian-Lagrangian method for simulating poroelastic materials, that is, elastic structures which are permeated by viscous fluid. This method can be used to simulate two-phase mixtures in contact with a single-phase fluid. The method provides an alternative to our fully Eulerian method, and it is particularly useful when one of the phases is a solid. We applied this method to study several problems related to cell mechanics. We used the model to explore the significance of the rheology of the cytoplasm in intracellular pressure propagation.  Experimental data on this problem had led to conflicting conclusions, but our results provided new clarity on the effects of cell rheology on intracellular pressure dynamics. We used our computational models in combination with experimental data to examine how large amoeboid cells coordinate cytoskeletal contraction, cytoplasmic streaming, and surface adhesion to crawl in confined spaces. The model explained precisely how the cell coordinates its adhesive interactions cortical contractions in order to move. Further, we showed that the particular method of adhesion coordination observed in the experiments produces is optimal in the sense of both migration speeds and robustness to the environment.


Many of our fluid-structure models are based ideas from the classical immersed boundary method. The immersed boundary method's inherent low accuracy has been an outstanding problem for over 30 years. There have been many attempts to increase its accuracy, with only limited success. In our work on viscoelastic fluids, we showed that the traditional immersed boundary method can produce the incorrect stress profile on the boundary. We developed a new method called the Immersed Boundary Smooth Extension method which is able to get high-order accuracy for problems involving stationary domains. We demonstrated up to fourth-order convergence on some model PDEs, and we extended our methodology to the equations of fluid mechanics.

We examined the locomotion of undulatory micro-organism swimming in complex fluids, and we were able to resolve some existing conflicting results from other studies.  Our model results highlighted the role of swimmer gait and body flexibility in determining the swimming speed. We showed that both favorable stroke asymmetry and swimmer elasticity contribute to a speed-up, but a substantial boost results only when these two effects work together. We reproduce conflicting results from the literature simply by changing relevant physical parameters. We extended this result to include an analysis of how flexibility affects swimming performance. This analysis provides new insight into how the elastic medium effects the resulting stroke of flexible swimmers.

We developed a new method for solving for the dynamics of a swimmer with a prescribed shape. We used this method to simulate a swimming alga cell based on the kinematic data. Our simulations provide new insight into how elastic stresses affect swimming micro-organisms in complex fluid environments. As part of this project, we explored viscoelastic flow around thin cylinders, and showed that the behavior of elastic stress is quite different from what one expects based on viscous fluid theory. These new results give new insight into the workings of cilia and flagella in complex fluids, which is important for understanding fertilization and mucus transport.

We used a computational model to explore the relevance of the stroke pattern in swimming crustaceans. We showed that the organisms used a stroke pattern that is optimal in terms of both speed and efficiency. This project was in collaboration with a team exploring the neural circuit driving the motion of the limbs. The distinct limb coordination in crustacean swimming and the relative simplicity of the neural coordinating circuit allowed us to show that the interlimb coordination in crustacean swimming is biomechanically optimal and how the structure of underlying neural circuit robustly gives rise to this coordination. Thus, we provide a concrete example of how an optimal behavior arises from the anatomical structure of a neural circuit. Furthermore, our results suggest that the connectivity of the neural circuit underlying limb coordination during crustacean swimming may be a consequence of natural selection in favor of more effective and efficient swimming.

Finally, this award partially supported 3 PhD students and one postdoc. All of the trainees worked on interdisciplinary projects and gained experience in mathematical modeling, scientific computing, working with real data, and communicating across disciplines.
